fine_print: * Temporary leave or suspension of duties is not sufficient to resolve the question as **Yes.** For example, if Bayrou takes medical leave that results in an acting Prime Minister being appointed, that will **not** be sufficient.

**Emmanuel Macron appoints François Bayrou as new Prime Minister of France**
French President Emmanuel Macron has appointed François Bayrou as the new Prime Minister of France, a key centrist ally. Bayrou, a 73-year-old politician, has been a close ally of Macron since his arrival at the Élysée Palace in 2017. He will be the fourth head of government this year and will replace the conservative Michel Barnier, nine days after the no-confidence vote that toppled his government, the shortest in the country since World War II. Bayrou has been a well-known figure in French politics for decades and his experience is seen as crucial in efforts to restore stability, as no party has a majority in the National Assembly. Macron promised last week to stay in office until the end of his term in 2027. The National Assembly voted down Barnier's government in a no-confidence motion on December 4, backed by left-wing and far-right groups, in a historic move in over half a century that paved the way for a new round of contacts. Macron opted to reach out to left-wing parties, excluding La France Insoumise, and dropped Marine Le Pen's National Rally, although it remains to be seen if the new government will be able to secure a minimum level of support among lawmakers and avoid future no-confidence motions. Olivier Faure, leader of the Socialist Party, who was considered a potential supporter, demanded during negotiations the appointment of a left-wing prime minister and ruled out supporting some of the names on the shortlist, including centrist François Bayrou. 'The President of the Republic has appointed François Bayrou as Prime Minister and entrusted him with the task of forming a government,' said the French presidency in a statement, without providing further details. Bayrou is the sixth prime minister of Macron's mandate and faces the immediate challenge of forming a cabinet that can survive a no-confidence motion in a deeply divided parliament and debate a 2025 budget in an attempt to limit economic turbulence. The announcement came after Macron received Bayrou for almost two hours of talks on Friday. BFMTV reported that the talks with Bayrou had been 'tense.' It was expected that Barnier would hand over power to his successor in a ceremony late on Friday morning. Bayrou's candidacy has caused unease on the left, which is wary of continuing Macron's policies, and on the right, where Nicolas Sarkozy's influential former presidency is not liked. Besides Bayrou, other candidates for prime minister include former Socialist Prime Minister Bernard Cazeneuve, Defense Minister Sébastien Lecornu, a loyal Macron supporter, and former Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian. Le Drian said on Thursday that he had rejected the position. 'I rejected it,' he told Le Penthievre, a regional weekly. 'In two and a half years, I will be 80 years old, it would not be a disaster.' Public opinion polls indicate that the public is fed up with the crisis, and more than two-thirds of respondents in a survey by Elabe published on Wednesday said they want politicians to reach an agreement to avoid toppling a new government. Each of Macron's prime ministers has been in office for less time successively, and there is no guarantee that the new prime minister will not follow this pattern. In a survey by IFOP, Le Pen obtained a 35% approval rating in the first round of a future presidential election, far ahead of any likely opponent. On a critical date, March 31, 2025, Le Pen faces the verdict in a trial for embezzlement of funds, which she denies. If she is found guilty, she could lose the opportunity to run in the 2027 election and, with it, her best chance so far of winning the Élysée Palace.

**François Bayrou Appointed as New Prime Minister of France**
French President Emmanuel Macron appointed François Bayrou, the leader of the 'Union for Democracy' party, as the new Prime Minister of France. Bayrou, a 73-year-old politician, has been a close ally of Macron since 2017 and has been considered a potential candidate for the position of Prime Minister on several occasions. Bayrou acknowledged the 'gravity of the situation' regarding the country's financial crisis, stating that 'I am aware of the difficulties that await us in the Himalayas, and the first of these difficulties is the budget'. His priority will be to restart the difficult process of drafting the 2025 budget, which has been stalled since the previous Prime Minister, Michel Barnier, was ousted. Bayrou will have to negotiate with various parties, including the 'National Rally' and the 'France Insoumise' parties, to secure their support for the government's policies, including the budget. The 'National Rally' party has announced that it will submit a motion of no-confidence against Bayrou's government, while the 'France Insoumise' party has stated that it will support the motion. The 'Green Party' has also announced that it will support the motion of no-confidence. Bayrou's appointment has been seen as a compromise between the different parties, and he has vowed to work towards finding a 'new path' to address the country's financial crisis.
